title: Better testing of optional serde
body: Complements #553 though it doesn't resolve it completely.

title: Refactor scientific precision for readability
body:
Follow up to #555.
This makes the code a little more verbose, hopefully making it a bit easier to follow. It now has two code paths: if precision is provided, and the default.

title: Support precision in `fmt_scientific_notation`
body: Currently the precision field is ignored when formatting a `Decimal` in scientific notation. This PR updates `fmt_scientific_notation` to respect the precision if specified.

title: Use the new feature resolver
body:
# Previous  behaviour

The usage of an optional feature always pulls the optional dependencies listed in the same feature even if these dependencies weren't explicitly required, which is generally undesired, surprising and slower.

```toml
[dependencies]
rgb = { default-features = false, optional = true, version = "0.8" }
serde = { default-features = false, optional = true, version = "1.0" }

[features]
# `with-serde` will always bring `serde` as well as `rgb`
with-serde = ["rgb/serde", "serde"]
```

# Current behaviour

With the new "weak dependency" feature, optional dependencies won't be automatically pulled effectively solving the above problem.

```toml
[dependencies]
rgb = { default-features = false, optional = true, version = "0.8" }
serde = { default-features = false, optional = true, version = "1.0" }

[features]
# `rgb` won't be included unless the `rgb` feature is required
with-serde = ["rgb?/serde", "serde"]
```

# Future behaviour

The "name-spaced dependency" feature enables the listing of optional features using the name of any optional dependency, so, instead of creating features with prefixes, suffices or funny names to avoid overlapping, it will be possible to group related stuff in intuitive names.

```toml
[dependencies]
rgb = { default-features = false, optional = true, version = "0.8" }
serde = { default-features = false, optional = true, version = "1.0" }

[features]
# `serde` can now be used as a feature with `dep:`
serde = ["rgb?/serde", "dep:serde"]
```

title: Documentation updates to include cargo-edit + more examples
Version 1.26.1
body: A hotfix release which doesn't meaningfully change behavior of the features but resolves documentation related issues.

title: Fixes feature compilation for docs.rs by favoring diesel2 if feature specified
body:
This removes the mutually exclusive pattern for `diesel1` and `diesel2` due to it breaking docs.rs downstream. Consequently, if both features are enabled then the latter will be favored.

Closes #535

title: Diesel 2 feature support
body:
This enables `diesel 2.0.0-rc.1` support via two new feature flags: `db-diesel2-mysql` and `db-diesel2-postgres`. In fact, to make things easier `diesel` features are now explicit (i.e. `db-diesel1-*`) with a backwards compatible feature flag pointing to version `1.4`.

Another notable change is that because of uncertainty building both `diesel1` and `diesel2` at the same time, I explicitly include a compiler error if both features are enabled. 

Subsequently, the build system needed to relax during the first build step. It built using `--all-features` however due to complexities with Serde configuration etc it was admittedly a little pointless. Sadly though, I can't use `--all-features` on `clippy` anymore - though as a future change I made move this to the makefile and process feature by feature. It'd be nice if `cargo` allowed you to _exclude_ features as that way we could avoid conflicting features. 

Anyway, this closes #531 and replaces #512 (though thank you for the quick and easy updates I could apply!)

title: Cleanup of database module
body: Start of some refactoring of the database modules to hopefully make supporting duplicate diesel versions a bit easier. This also fixes some bugs in the `Makefile` - tests weren't being run as per expectations after some recent (?) refactoring.

title: Add num_traits `Signed` to prelude
body:
First of all, thanks for the awesome crate!

Currently the `.signum()` method cannot be used when importing `prelude` without adding `num-traits` as a specific dependency in a downstream crate and importing manually. 

Other used `num_traits` traits are currently reexported under the prelude module so I think this tiny change to align makes sense? 

Example error message when trying to use currently:  

```
error[E0599]: no method named `signum` found for struct `rust_decimal::Decimal` in the current scope
   --> mycode/mod.rs:465:88
    |
465 |             myvalue.signum();
    |                     ^^^^^^ method not found in `rust_decimal::Decimal`
    |
   ::: /home/james/.cargo/registry/src/github.com-1ecc6299db9ec823/num-traits-0.2.14/src/sign.rs:35:8
    |
35  |     fn signum(&self) -> Self;
    |        ------ the method is available for `rust_decimal::Decimal` here
    |
    = help: items from traits can only be used if the trait is in scope
help: the following trait is implemented but not in scope; perhaps add a `use` for it:
    |
1   | use num_traits::sign::Signed;```

title: Relax minimum version requirements in readme
Add MySQL support for Diesel
body:
Fixes #439 

Unfortunately, the spec for the `decimal` protocol in MySQL isn't complete: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/internals/en/binary-protocol-value.html#packet-ProtocolBinary::MYSQL_TYPE_DECIMAL

Reverse engineering some other libraries, including official connectors, it appears that it simply uses a binary string format for decimals.

title: Add support for Rocket forms
body:
Hello!

Here's a simple implementation for [Rocket](https://rocket.rs)'s [`FromFormField`](https://api.rocket.rs/v0.5-rc/rocket/form/trait.FromFormField.html).

This allows reading `Decimal`s straight from web form fields (either bodies or query strings).

I'm not sure if the feature name is good enough, but i couldn't think of any other. I've also added a test. Should i add a failing one as well?

title: Fixed integer handling in Decimal::to_f64
body:
We've discovered this issue in to_64, in the code branch that handles decimals with scale 0. The assumption in the original code was that if the value can only be represented in f64 if it can fit into i64. There is no reason for such limit, 96-bit integers can be represented by f64.
(If the intent was to only allow representing integers with no precision loss, which I doubt, then the original code is also incorrect since f64 can only represent integers of up to 53 bits without rounding).

title: Feature: Retain excess precision during float conversions
body:
Fixes #438 

Additional functions `from_f32_retain` and `from_f64_retain` created to retain additional float bits while parsing `f32`/`f64` respectively.

title: Fixes significant figure calcs for small numbers
body:
Fixes #437 

The previous code incorrectly assumed that numbers right of the decimal point when `0 < x < 1` were significant. For example, `0.0012301` would calculate as `7` significant figures. According to various literature ([example](http://www.ruf.rice.edu/~kekule/SignificantFigureRules1.pdf)), because the first two zeros are not involved in measurement decisions they can be simplified as to how it is represented. In the case above we could simplify to `1.2301 x 10^-3` consequently requiring only `5` significant figures to represent. 
Because Rust Decimal implicitly stores numbers like this beneath the surface (e.g. above would be stored as `12301 x 10^-7`) we can easily extract the significant figures by relying on the mantissa only.

The logic for SF rounding currently leverages the difference between current sf and requested sf to perform calculation. Using the same example, if we were trying to round to 3 significant figures then previously we would try to adjust by `7 - 3 = 4` decimal points which would result in `0.001` (`1 x 10^-3`) i.e. it assumes that the `0`s are significant.

The new code aligns with the literature and instead ignores the leading `0`s. The dp adjustment used is `5 - 3 = 2` which consequently gives the result `0.00123` (`123 x 10^-5`) i.e. the leading `0`s are not significant.

title: Auto rounding of scales 29, 30 and 31 for deserialization
body:
Removes introduced panic by leveraging an automatic round. Still a breaking change due to `const` being removed (i.e. `mut` prevents `const` right now) however is closer than before by avoiding a runtime panic.

Fixes #435

title: Fixes issue with mantissa sf calculation
body: Fixes #430

title: Fixes Display Overflow issue when using precision greater than 30
body:
This fixes #428 to allow for string formatting with precision of greater than 30. It maintains fast string allocation for strings <30 and reverts to appending the slower `String` when greater precision is required.

Expands upon PR #432 by @c410-f3r.

Contains a breaking change for scenarios that require `deserialize` to be a `const` function.  If this is required then I could create a feature to force `const` at the expense of no constraint check - at least until `const panic` is stabilized.

title: Add benchmarks to compare different structures
body:
Only compares floating primitives with arithmetic operations using equal and different left and right hand values.

![add](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17877264/130302200-cb1ea1cb-c048-4eb6-a867-4978bfbffbf1.jpg)
![div](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17877264/130302259-90c3bb46-8f6a-4f31-bd6b-6fcce6fc2e4c.jpg)

Quite interesting results

title: Add benchmarks to compare different structures
body:
Useful to see how `rust-decimal` is performing compared to other libraries or how much is lagging behind `f32` or `f64` hardware based operations.

![addition](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17877264/129458061-82c68e19-3cf0-48a2-be0d-a1c70ed7ab46.jpg)
![division](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17877264/129458091-cf613144-bdbc-47dc-9848-4ec4bbf719d4.jpg)
![subtration](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17877264/129458100-b938c42e-47da-4036-9b5c-75c0ca2209cd.jpg)
![multiplication](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17877264/129458110-a9ec31a1-fa48-4730-b835-d829bf3cbd27.jpg)

As seen from above, `rust-decimal` is the fastest decimal library with operations ~2000% slower if compared to native primitives.

title: Trigonometry Support
body:
Resolves #379 
Adds in support for `sin` and `cos` with a tested precision of `10^-10` and for `tan` with a tested precision of `10^-8`. `tan` has the caveat that values of x approaching the limit may lose some accuracy.

title: Enable all fuzz tests
body:
After running for a while, no panic occurred so it seems that `let mut result = self + Decimal::ONE;` was the sole culprit.
It is worth noting that although no panic occurred on my local tests and no panic can occur after running the fuzz targets for many years, all explicit arithmetic operator (`+`, `*`, `-`, `%`, etc) should be audited to catch any possible corner-case.

title: Version/1.15
body:
Fixes #395.
Fixes #380.

title: Round f64 before final conversion in to_f64
body: This fixes the issue described in #401 by rounding the `f64` before attempting to reduce precision.

title: log 10 implementation
body:
Implements `log10` as well as `checked_` functions for `ln` and `log10`. To maintain backwards compatibility in regards to "no panics" a feature `maths-nopanic` has been introduced. While it's not truly backwards compatible, it does allow for previous behavior to be re-instated. Closes #397.

This also introduces a number of constants since a few were required for the `ln` algorithm. Fixes #400.

title: Fix negative zero serialization bug
body:
When negative zero (`-Decimal::ZERO`) is serialized, it becomes `"-"`

This commit fixes that bug

body: My bad. The `?` operator immediately returns the closure so, for example, an input that could spot a bug on the last arithmetic function will never be exercised if the first function returns early.

title: Added additional documentation to clear up maths feature vs standard ops support
body: Hopefully this will help avoid library confusion such as this: https://users.rust-lang.org/t/rust-decimal-manipulation-support/58527

title: Added powx functions to support decimal powers
body:
Closes #169.

This has a small breaking change whereby `powi(u64)` has been renamed `powu(u64)` allowing `powi(i64)` to be introduced. Also adds in `powf` and `powd` functions leveraging `pow` via the `num_traits::pow::Pow` trait.

This also optimizes `exp` a bit to ensure we get closer approximations. More work can definitely be done in the future to optimize this further providing a wider range of results, increased accuracy of approximations and faster calculations.
